The JavaScript interpreter needs to execute the constant declaration for size before the name size can be used in an expression. In this online book, the statements that need to be evaluated before a new statement are omitted for brevity. However, in order to see and play with the program, you can click on it. You notice here that JavaScript statements can be placed in a sequence. The interpreter evaluates the components of the sequence in the given order, and treats the value of the last component as the value of the sequence.

is our languages simplest means of abstraction, for it allows us to use simple names to refer to the results of compound operations, such as the circumference computed above. In general, computational objects may have very complex structures, and it would be extremely inconvenient to have to remember and repeat their details each time we want to use them. Indeed, complex programs are constructed by building, step by step, computational objects of increasing complexity. The interpreter makes this step-by-step program construction particularly convenient because name-object associations can be created incrementally in successive interactions. It should be clear that the possibility of associating values with names and later retrieving them means that the interpreter must maintain some sort of memory that keeps track of the name-object pairs. This memory is called the environment environment (more precisely the
global environment global environment,
program environment program environment,
since we will see later that a computation may involve a number of different environments).Chapter3 will show that this notion of environment is crucial, both for understanding how the interpreter works and for implementing interpreters.
